abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Transport Project's
            outcome was rated as satisfactory. Overall, the project was
            well- designed and performed. The roads constructed showed
            high and robust economic returns, and overall objectives are
            likely to be achieved. The project revealed key limitations
            of the project approach, as opposed to the program approach,
            thus underscoring the need to place urban transport
            development in an integrated context. Key lessons learned
            from this project include: a) Future urban projects should
            increase interaction with beneficiary communities to educate
            them on the limits of projects and their respective roles.
            b) Advance publicity and education campaign is necessary to
            prepare the public for new concepts such as non-motorist
            transport. Operation of the facilities requires the
            definition of a role for law enforcement agencies. c)
            Relocation of utility services prior to the main contract
            reduced delays and minimized costs. d) Future consideration
            for terminal rehabilitation should ensure that there is
            enough evidence that the recipient assemblies control the
            terminals and have power and commitment to introduce cost
            recovery measures. e) An urban public transport policy
            should be developed with inputs from stakeholders to ensure
            effective usage of the roadway thus reducing congestion and
            other disadvantages. f) Levels of governments matching funds
            for projects must be released timely to reduce unnecessary
            costs associated with delayed payments for contracts.
